# Draft:Soomra–Tughlaq War

The Soomra–Tughlaq War was a conflict fought between the Soomra dynasty of Sindh and the Tughlaq dynasty of Delhi around 1351 CE.
The Soomras were supported by Mongol forces under Amir Farghan, the rebel Taghi (a former general of Muhammad bin Tughluq), and Jam Unar of the Samma dynasty.
The war resulted in a Soomra victory, and the imperial Tughlaq forces were heavily plundered.
Background
During the reign of Muhammad bin Tughluq, internal revolts weakened the Delhi Sultanate. One of his generals, Taghi, rebelled against him and fled to lower Sindh, where he was sheltered by the Soomras.
With support from the Mongol commander Amir Farghan and the Samma ruler Jam Unar, the Soomras prepared to attack the Tughlaq forces in Sindh.
The War
The Soomra forces, led by Sultan Hamir bin Dodo IV Soomro, attacked the Tughlaq imperial army from the rear, while the Mongols struck from the front.
The combined armies looted and plundered the imperial camp, seized wealth, captured harems, and inflicted heavy losses on the Tughlaq forces.
Aftermath
The defeat at Hyderabad severely weakened Tughlaq influence in Sindh. The Soomra alliance with Taghi, the Mongols, and the Sammas ensured that the Delhi Sultanate could not consolidate its power in the region.
